headline: Why severe pneumonia can cause death –Physician
summarized_story:
For the layman, we say anytime you have germs that are multiplying in the lungs, that is pneumonia.
Now, it is one thing to distinguish bacterial pneumonia from viral pneumonia or fungal pneumonia and so on.
But to ascertain the type of fungal pneumonia or bacterial pneumonia, for instance, is another thing altogether because bacteria and viruses are in their millions.
If you live in a face-me-I-face-you, where people sometimes cook with kerosene along the corridor, that exposes one to pneumonia.
But the prevention of pneumonia is outside medicine and the doctors and more of government regulation and personal choice.

headline: Southern governors' communique and its discontents
summarized_story:
It is salutary that the southern governors have raised the matter of marginalization of southerners in the most important aspect of modern governance.
Even if the federal attorney-general’s condemnation of the southern governors’ communique is an official response on behalf of the executive branch or the Senate President’s theory that elected members of government should put in abeyance their right to speak for the regions they govern is designed to serve the interest of the central government, citizens’ reviews of the communique suggest that citizens are listening to southern governors with rapt attention.
ADVERTISEMENTThe significance of the long overdue meeting of southern governors may not be felt noticeably at present.
There is no better way to run subnational governments in a federation than for any section of the subnational governments not to seem to lose its capacity to speak up on matters that have dehumanized its constituents.
Though rather belated, this column congratulates the southern governors for banning open grazing of cattle and other ruminats in the region and committing to support and facilitate modern ranching in the region.

headline: Does the Nigerian government want safety or surveillance with its new IMEI policy?
summarized_story:
From July 2021, the Nigerian Communications Commission (NCC) will require Nigerians to submit their IMEI numbers to a Centralised Equipment Identity Register.
The International Mobile Equipment Identity (IMEI) is a unique number used to identify a mobile phone.
With an IMEI number, a phone can be tracked, but more than that, it can also be used for identity theft and even cloning a phone.
AdvertisementIf a phone owner possesses their IMEI number, they could provide law enforcement agencies with this information to track these phones if they are stolen.
Adding IMEI data to this would mean that they can also get real-time location data on anyone.

headline: Tax compliance: EIRS visits govt multinational companies on enforcement drive – Nigerian Observer
summarized_story:
Share FacebookTwitterStumbleuponLinkedInPinterestBENIN CITY – Edo State Internal Revenue Service (EIRS), has called on government institutions and multinational companies in Edo State to be tax compliant to avoid being sanctioned.
The charge was given during visits by the EIRS compliance team to the Nigerian Petroleum Development Company (NPDC) Liquified Petroleum Gas (LPG) Terminal in Ologbo and the Nigerian Bottling Company (NBC), both in Edo State.
EIRS Executive Director, Income Tax, Prince Felix Isuku, stated: “the visit was to ensure that both organizations, and others operating in Edo State, comply with tax laws, as they are legally bound to do so.”He warned that “just as there are rewards for compliance, there are also sanctions.”Isuku reiterated the need for all organizations to ensure they register with the EIRS, deduct and remit Pay-As-You-Earn (PAYE), withholding taxes, pay haulage fees, carry out business premises registration and renewal fees, as well as ensure the verification of tax clearance certificates.
Isuku stressed the need for organizations and multinationals in Edo to play their part towards achieving the plans of making Edo great again.
The Plant Manager, Nigerian Bottling Company (NBC), Irene Okpode, expressed appreciation to the EIRS team for the visit, promising a smooth working relationship with the Service and to sustain compliance with the tax laws.

headline: Plateau gov, Lalong mourns death of NASCO founder, Ahmed Nasreddin
summarized_story:
Simon Lalong, governor of Plateau, has condoled with the NASCO family, over the passing of the founder of the NASCO Group of Companies, Mr Ahmed Nasreddin, who died at the age of 97.
The governor in a condolence message by his Director of Press and Public Affairs, Dr Makut Macham, on Saturday in Jos, expressed grief over the death of the nonagenarians.

headline: Katsina Emirate sacks Kankara District Head for allegedly sponsoring bandits, insurgents
summarized_story:

The Spokesman of the Emirate, Alhaji Ibrahim Bindawa stated on Friday before the dismissal that the District Head was suspended earlier for allegedly sponsoring the activities of bandits in Kankara, one of the frontline Local Government Areas bedeviled by insecurity in the state.
“A committee was set up by the Emirate and was chaired by the Kauran Katsina, District Head of Rimi, after meeting security officials and other stakeholders especially from the Kankara district found the District Head guilty of aiding bandits and kidnappers terrorising Kankara LGA.
“Upon completion of the investigation, the Emirate found him guilty and submitted its report to the State Government where the Government further directed the Emirate to dismiss him,” Bindawa explained.

headline: Oshoala named Nigeria’s ‘All-Time greatest Female Player’
summarized_story:

After the results of a poll published on CAF’s women’s verified Twitter handle, Oshoala was named the greatest female player to emerge from Nigeria.
She defeated legendary Nigerian female stars Mercy Akide, Perpetual Nkwocha, and Cynthia Uwak.

headline: Governor Ortom tells Benue residents to defend themselves from external attacks

Ortom admonished the people of the state to put politics aside and join hands with the government to fight for the survival and soul of Benue State, which he said was under siege.
The wife of the governor, Mrs. Eunice Ortom; the Speaker of the state House of Assembly, Titus Uba; Senator Abba Moro; former Deputy Governor, Chief Steven Lawani; and members of the Benue State Security and Executive Council attended the ceremony.
